Lack enough support: The claim lacks enough support as it is based on a video clip that has been doctored and does not accurately represent the incident it claims to depict.
Problematic assumption: The claim assumes that the chant of "Allah Hu Akbar" caused fear in Donald Trump, without providing any evidence or context to support this assumption.
Exist alternative explanation: The alternative explanation is that the incident in the video clip occurred in May 2016 at a campaign event in Dayton, Ohio, where a protester attempted to breach the security cordon and was swiftly removed by Secret Service agents. The chant of "Allah Hu Akbar" was not the cause of fear, but rather the attempt to breach security.
Contradict fact: The claim contradicts the fact that the video clip has been doctored and does not accurately depict the incident it claims to show.
Exaggerate: The claim exaggerates the impact of the chant of "Allah Hu Akbar" by suggesting that it scared Donald Trump, without providing any evidence to support this exaggeration.
Understate: There is no evidence of any understatement bias in the claim.
Falters at times: There is no evidence of any faltering bias in the claim.
